title: 106_s148
content:
The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate among countries, with many wintering in Latin America and the Caribbean. These neotropical migratory birds provide valuable benefits to the environment and economy. However, their populations are declining due to habitat loss and degradation. The conservation of neotropical migratory birds is crucial due to habitat loss and degradation across their range. International cooperation is necessary for their conservation efforts to be effective and initiatives can be improved through better coordination. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, assist in their conservation through initiatives in the US, Latin America, and the Caribbean, and provide financial resources for international cooperation. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

    In this Act:
        (1) Account.--The term ``Account'' means the Neotropical 
    Migratory Bird Conservation Account established by section 9(a).
        (2) Conservation.--The term ``conservation'' means methods necessary to ensure long-term viability of neotropical migratory bird species, including protection, habitat management, research, law enforcement, and community outreach.
        (3) Secretary.--The term ``Secretary'' means the Secretary of 
    the Interior. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities, including individuals, government agencies, and international organizations. To be considered for financial assistance under the International Organizations Immunities Act, an applicant must submit a project proposal that includes the name of the project leader, project goals, qualifications of project staff, estimated funds and time needed, sources of matching funds, and a focus on enhancing neotropical migratory bird conservation in the US, Latin America, or the Caribbean with mechanisms for local public participation. The project proposal for financial assistance under the International Organizations Immunities Act must include mechanisms for local public participation, consultation with wildlife management authorities, sensitivity to local resources, compliance with laws, promotion of sustainable bird conservation programs, and any other necessary information for evaluation. Recipients of assistance must submit periodic reports to the Secretary. The project proposal for financial assistance under the International Organizations Immunities Act must include mechanisms for local public participation, consultation with wildlife management authorities, sensitivity to local resources, compliance with laws, promotion of sustainable bird conservation programs, and any other necessary information for evaluation. Recipients of assistance must submit periodic reports to the Secretary, including all required information for evaluating the progress and outcome of the project. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25 percent, and the non-Federal share must not come from any Federal grant program, with cash payment required for projects in the United States and foreign countries. For projects in the United States, the non-Federal share must be paid in cash. In foreign countries, the non-Federal share can be paid in cash or in kind. The Secretary's duties under the Act include developing guidelines for project proposals, encouraging submissions from wildlife management authorities, selecting proposals that meet requirements and conservation needs, and implementing the Act. Cooperation is also emphasized. The Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, exchanging information, entering agreements, and coordinating activities with existing conservation projects. An advisory group may be convened to assist in carrying out the Act. The Secretary may convene an advisory group consisting of individuals representing organizations involved in neotropical migratory bird conservation. The advisory group's meetings must be open to the public, provide opportunities for public input, and have timely notice and minutes available to the public. The advisory group's meetings must have minutes kept by the Secretary and made available to the public. The group is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, on the program's results and effectiveness under this Act, with recommendations for improvements and whether the program should continue. Additionally, there is a Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account established. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury to receive donations and appropriations. The Secretary of the Treasury can use the funds for program implementation without further appropriation, with a limit of 3% or $80,000 for administrative expenses. The Secretary can use donations and appropriations for program implementation, with a limit of 3% or $80,000 for administrative expenses. Authorization of appropriations for the Account to carry out the Act is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005, with a requirement that at least 75 percent of the funds be used for projects outside the United States.
